docs.lead_paragraph: It seemed innocuous enough. The managed-care industry began a high-profile campaign late last year to reassure consumers that it was, as its slogan said, Putting Patients First. But an organization for people with chronic diseases had already used that same phrase as the title for a manifesto of patients' rights, which it said were threatened by the stampede to managed care.

headline.main: Name-Calling Becomes Part of the Struggle to Define the Health Care Debate

docs.abstract: National Health Council and American Association of Health Plans, which represents patients and health-maintenance organizations respectively, are locked in testy debate over who is entitled to use slogan, Putting Patients First; Council has used it as title for manifesto on patients rights, while lobby for health maintenance organizations used it earlier as part of high-profile advertising campaign to reassure consumers; fight symbolizes agony and imagery of health care industry as doctors, hospitals and insurancxe companies try to outdo one another by proclaiming their commitment to consumers in fiercely competitive market (M)
